LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Islamic Republic of Pakistan 
   
The Proposal  The proposed Sindh Devolved Social Services Program (DSSP) comprises 
two program loans and a technical assistance (TA) loan to support financing, 
capacity  building,  partnership  building  and  reforms  of  Sindh’s  devolved 
social services: education, health, and drinking water and sanitation.    
   
Classification  Poverty intervention 
Thematic: Human development; good governance  
   
Environment  Category B.  Environmental assessment of the policy matrix was undertaken 
Assessment  and is available as a supplementary appendix. 
 
Rationale  Sindh’s  social  indicators  have  remained  well  behind  its  economic 
performance, with high levels of illiteracy, malnutrition and mortality. The 
poor social status has a major impact on its economy, environment, and 
water resources; and are directly linked to the poverty and gender complex 
that  needs  to  be  addressed.  Public  social  services—education,  health, 
nutrition,  population  welfare,  and  water  and  sanitation—are  run-down, 
primarily due to  chronic problems in governance, capacity, and financing. 
The  Social  Action  Program  (1992–2002)  had  mixed  results  due  to  the 
prevailing economic problems of the 1990s, the time it took to generate 
commitment for social services, and the lack of focus on service delivery and 
related governance.    
 
In the past 3 years, a policy framework has been put in place comprising the 
Poverty Reduction Strategy and Program, the Local Government Ordinance, 
sector specific policies and program, and the Sindh Reform Program. The 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  is  supporting  administrative  and  fiscal 
devolution through the Decentralization Support Program, while the Access 
to Justice Program supports legal and judiciary reforms. The Sindh Reform 
Program is addressing macro financial and administrative issues with the 
support  of  the  World  Bank’s  Structural  Adjustment  Credit.  The  Sindh 
Provincial Government (SPG) is committed to poverty reduction, devolution, 
and social sector development toward the Millennium Development Goals, 
and has requested ADB to provide program support for devolved social 
services  in  the  province.  Pakistan’s  devolution  provides  a  window  of 
opportunities  to  undertake  reforms  in  the  social  services.  Initial 
improvements have been noted and local bodies are eager to move ahead. 
However, they need both technical and financial support to do so. The Local 
Government Ordinance supports greater involvement of community-based 
organizations  (CBOs),  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  and  the 
private  sector.  These  have  become  important  forces  in  social  services 
expansion,  and  the  transition  provides  a  unique  opportunity  to  develop 
partnerships. The proposed approach—flexible support to local governments 
to carry out their own agenda based on certain terms and conditions to 
ensure accountability and maximize benefits for the poor—reflects the major 
thrust that emerged from the participatory planning process undertaken.

iii 
Objectives and  The overall goal of the DSSP is to improve people’s education and health, 
Scope  thereby  helping  to  reduce  poverty  and  gender  imbalances.  The  broad 
purpose is to increase school enrolment, and coverage with health and clear 
water and sanitation services. These objectives are to be primarily achieved 
by improving governance and financing of social services; that should result 
in increased  access to basic social services, in particular for women; and 
improved quality, efficiency, affordability and sustainability of services.  
 
The  Program  has  5  principal  policy  outcomes,  namely,  to  (i)  further 
administrative  devolution  of  social  services,  (ii)  improve  social  sector 
financing and flow of funds, (iii) promote participation, linkages, and public 
accountability, (iv) rationalize services and set minimum standards, and (v) 
encourage public-private partnership.  
 
The  DSSP  covers  all  16  districts  and  102  taluka/town  municipal 
administrations (TMAs) of Sindh for a time slice of 3 years for the program 
loans and 4 years for the TA loan.  
 
In the education sector, SPG will expand support to school management 
committees of schools up to class 12 to improve and operate these schools; 
and  provide  additional  assistance  for  rehabilitating  schools,  constructing 
facilities  for  functioning  but  shelterless  schools,  home  schools  for  girls, 
textbooks, stipends for girls, and contracting local female teachers on merit.  
 
In the health, nutrition and population welfare sector, SPG will promote the 
basic  package  of  health  services,  contract  female  staff,  support  the 
establishment  of  health  board  and  patients  associations  to  improve  the 
maintenance  and  operations  of  health  facilities,  and  introduce  financial 
reforms to improve the quality, affordability, and continuity of health services.  
   
In the drinking water and sanitation sector, SPG will build the capacity of 
TMAs to conduct infrastructure and consumer surveys and develop master 
plans; develop interim policies for drinking water, sanitation, and solid waste 
management;  and  improve  basic  water  and  sanitation  services  through 
partnership with communities.  
 
SPG proposes five areas of policy actions focusing on good governance.   
 
First,  as  per  Sindh’s  Local  Governance  Ordinance,  SPG  plans  further 
devolution  of  administrative  and  financial  powers  to  local  governments 
(LGs), including preparation of the annual development program, personnel 
management, and financial authority. It also plans to strengthen delegation 
within  the  local  governments  and  adjust  the  roles  of  provincial  line 
departments toward providing policy, monitoring and technical support. 
 
Second, SPG proposes to increase social sector financing above the normal 
social  sector  share  of  total  revenues;  use  a  needs-based,  transparent 
formula  for  distributing  conditional  grants  for  social  sector  development; 
improve the flow of funds; and improve financial management.

iv        
  Third,  SPG  proposes  to  improve  participation  and  accountability  by 
encouraging participatory planning in LGs, implementing the Gender Reform 
Action Plan, improving public information, and adopting the mechanism of 
management  agreements  between  the  provincial  government  and  LGs 
spelling out the terms and conditions for grant support to LGs to ensure that 
funds are well used while maintaining flexibility in the use of funds. 
 
Fourth,  SPG  proposes  pro-poor  rationalization  of  services  and  setting 
minimum standards, using the annual planning cycle and access to grants 
for  LG  plans.  It  proposes  restrictions  on  new  construction,  selective 
recruitment of female staff, a minimal set of interventions to be considered in 
all plans, support of CBOs, and proper planning and monitoring procedures. 
SPG line departments will lead studies on sector policy reforms.  
 
Fifth, SPG proposes financial and technical support for CBOs in operating 
and maintaining social services, particularly expanding support for school 
management  committees  in  all  schools,  but  also  encouraging  similar 
developments in the health and water and sanitation sectors.

I.   THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on: (i) two proposed 
program loans, and (ii) a proposed technical assistance loan to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan 
for the Sindh Devolved Social Services Program (DSSP). 
 
 
II.  THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT    
 
2.  Pakistan’s economic growth of about 6% gross domestic product (GDP) before the 
1990s was largely based on external capital inflows, resulting in major structural imbalances in 
public finance.1 In the 1990s, the country’s rapid accumulation of debts resulted in serious fiscal 
constraints and deterioration of social indicators despite efforts under the Social Action Program 
(SAP). Since 2000, however, the fiscal balance and other indicators of the economy have 
improved dramatically. Because of macroeconomic stabilization, and economic and governance 
reforms pursued by the Government of Pakistan (Government) in the preceding 3 years, and 
some  developments  after  11  September  2001  key  macroeconomic  fundamentals  during 
FY2003 were much better than at any other time in the past decade. Despite this strong growth2 
and improvements in other key macroeconomic indicators such as inflation, fiscal deficits, 
exports, and reserve holdings, investment failed to pick up due partly to excess capacity in 
many  industries  and  a  wait-and-see  attitude  of  investors  in  an  environment  of  political 
uncertainty. Fixed capital accumulation is expected to pick up once the excess capacity is 
exhausted and if economic recovery is sustained.3 Economic growth will depend on regional 
and political stability, a benign external environment for debt servicing and investment, and 
progress in the reform and development agenda under the new political and administrative 
setup after devolution.4   
 
3.  While the Government is on a fast track toward economic recovery and debt reduction, 
its tax reforms are slow. The situation causes pressure on public sector funding to implement 
the commitments made at the Pakistan Development Forum and threatens to undermine two 
major initiatives: (i) the Poverty Reduction Strategy and Program (PRSP), and (ii) the devolution 
program.  These  initiatives  are  expected  to  help  Pakistan  move  toward  the  Millennium 
Development Goals (MDGs); they also require major additional resources for pro-poor services, 
and administrative costs and up-front financing of local governments (LGs). Poverty reduction is 
the key objective of the Government's economic policies.5 Under its poverty reduction strategy 
the Government is committed to increasing poverty reducing public expenditure as a percentage 
of GDP, including in the education, health, drinking water supply, and sanitation sectors by 
about 15% each year. Pro-poor expenditure incurred in FY2003 showed a sharp increase of 
nearly 30% compared with that in FY2002, but fell short of its target of PRs161 billion. As a 
percentage of the annual GDP, the pro-poor expenditure increased from about 2.2% in FY2002

4.  The provinces are expected to contribute to financing these initiatives. Federal transfers 
(from the divisible pool of taxes and in the form of straight transfers) increased at an accelerated 
rate of  20% per annum between FY1999 and FY2003. However, this was not enough to 
compensate for the increased provincial obligations to support LGs. Responsibilities for basic 
services were devolved without the modalities for fiscal decentralization in place. The situation 
is particularly acute in Sindh, which has some of the worst social indicators and underspending 
in  the  social  sector,  a  serious  budget  deficit,  and  a  complex  political  situation.  General 
administrative  and  social  services  spending  has  doubled  in  5  years.  Sindh’s  budget  has 
increased from PRs51.7 billion in FY1999 to PRs99.3 billion in FY2003, while its budget deficit 
has increased from PRs9.9 billion to PRs18.6 billion over that period. Sindh is facing a debt 
stock of about PRs116 billion (about $2 billion) and debt servicing levels of PRs1.8 billion (about 
$300 million) per annum. To cope with the situation, the Sindh provincial government (SPG) has 
adopted a proactive strategy and retired about PRS 1.8 billion in expensive domestic debt in the 
past 2 years to create more fiscal space. However, this has also constrained social sector 
spending, particularly for devolved services, which is still only  $11 per capita for education, 
health and drinking water supply and sanitation.  
 
5.  In FY2001, SPG embarked on the Sindh Reform Program, supported by the World 
Bank’s Sindh structural adjustment credit (SAC) to improve the overall governance and fiscal 
situation. The program includes tax and civil service reforms, improved governance in the 
financial sector, and creating fiscal space for increased social sector spending.  Progress in 
achieving the objectives of the reform program was impressive in FY2001 and FY2002. Owing 
to  tighter  budgetary  controls,  exercise  of  greater  fiscal  prudence,  and  reprioritization  of 
expenditures, the total spending of SPG grew at a slower pace of 16% per annum in FY2001 
and FY2002 compared with 29% in FY1999 and FY2000. Revenues of the province from own 
sources, which contribute close to 16% of all provincial revenues, grew at 9% per annum during 
FY2000–FY2002. Since FY2003, however, growth in provincial revenues has slowed down to 
less than 5%, while fiscal stress increased due to accelerated debt repayments, the cost of 
devolution and the poverty reduction agenda, and the decision of the federal Government to 
enhance salaries of government employees.  
 
6.  It comes as no surprise then that Sindh’s annual development plan is actually financed 
out of savings that occur during the fiscal year and from foreign project assistance. Put in 
another way, the entire annual development plan of SPG is a form of deficit financing, which is 
only met by savings from the salary component or cutting down on nonsalary expenditures. 
Because of these severe fiscal constraints, SPG is forced to resort to a number of tactics, 
including  delaying  releases  of  funds  and  cutting  down  on  nonsalary  and  development 
components. At the same time, there is a huge gap between the functional obligations of LGs, 
including district governments (DGs) and taluka6/town municipal administrations (TMAs), and 
the financial resources and tax bases within their control. The process of transferring property 
taxes to TMAs has also been very slow, and TMAs have not been receiving their full share of 
property taxes on time. While a total of PRs10 billion has been deducted at source for utilities to 
clear all arrears up to December 2002, it left  TMAs without funds for water and sanitation 
services.

  III.  THE SECTOR 
 
A.  Sector Description and Performance   
 
1.  Poverty and Social Status 
 
9.  Sindh is the southern province of Pakistan. Half of its population of about 35 million live 
in urban areas, most of them in Karachi, the economic hub of Pakistan with a population of 12 
million. The  average per capita income is about $450 per person per year. Poverty has 
increased from 27% in 1999 to 37% in 2001. About one third of the urban population and two 
thirds of the rural population live on less than about $1 a day. Drought is common in Sindh, and 
particularly affects the population dependent on nonirrigated lands. Only 17% of the land area 
has sweet water. Rural poverty, unemployment, high fertility, and exploitation result in high 
rural-urban migration, with Karachi’s population growing at the rate of about 6% per year and a 
slum population of about 3 million.  
 
10.  Defining poverty as  overall human deprivation comprising limited opportunities, social 
exclusion, and vulnerability to exogenous shocks, an estimated 50% of the population lives 
below the poverty line. In addition to low income, poor households are characterized by low 
levels of education, lack of safe water, and unmet needs for population welfare services. The 
Social Policy and Development Center8 ranked districts according to 11 social and 16 economic 
development indicators. The Center identified Tharparkar, Thatta, Badin, Jacobabad, Ghotki, 
Mirpur Khas, Sanghar and Shikarpur as the most deprived districts.  
 
11.  Two thirds of  women and one third of people above 10 years of age in Sindh are 
illiterate. Half of school-age children are not in school for reasons of poverty and lack of proper 
schools and instruction. The situation is worse in rural areas.  Nearly 15,000 schools are 
shelterless, while nearly 4,000 are closed due to nonavailability of resources. Participation rates 
have stagnated. Women face the additional burden of gender discrimination. Gross enrollment 
is 38% for girls and 61% for boys. Key social indicators are in Appendix 2  (sector analysis).

12.  Married women have on average about 5 children, and maternal mortality is high. The

13.  About 10% of infants die before 1 year of age.  Pneumonia, diarrheal diseases, and 
perinatal diseases account for 70% of infant deaths. Only 50% of infants are fully immunized. 
Frequent illnesses, food shortages, and inadequate care cause half of the children below the 
age of 5 to be underweight. About 45% of rural households use heavily contaminated water 
from uncovered wells, rivers, and ponds; and 53% do not have private toilet facilities. In urban 
areas,  major  problems  are  the  chronic  shortage  of  drinking  water,  pipe  leakage  and 
contaminated water, and low cost recovery. Urban slum dwellers live in very poor environmental 
conditions, lacking services in solid waste management and access to sewerage systems. 
 
  2.  Social Sector Development 
 
14.  SPG operates an extensive network of education, health, and drinking water supply 
services. Centrally located services are often overused, while remote facilities are often run-
down or closed. Common problems among social services are (i) lack of funds for operation and 
maintenance; (ii) poor quality of services due to poor staff performance; (iii) lack of access for 
women and girls due to a shortage of female staff, particularly in rural areas; (iv) prohibitive cost 
of services for the very poor; (v) weak management, supervision, and monitoring due to 
governance problems; and (vi) limited stakeholder involvement and public accountability.   
 
15.  During the past decade, Sindh implemented SAP9 as an effort to uplift the social sector. 
The SAP experience had mixed results.10 Primary and middle school enrollments could barely 
keep up with population growth. Studies suggest run-down schools, costs, and opportunity costs 
in association with poverty and drought as the main causes. Immunization coverage, another 
core indicator, also stagnated, perhaps due to management constraints created by the added 
burden of the polio eradication campaign. Child mortality was reduced, but this may in part be 
attributed to private sector development and secular trends. There was substantial progress in 
family planning services. In the water sector, the focus was on handing over schemes to 
communities, hence there was little improvement in access to safe drinking water.  
 
16.  Overall, SAP helped increase political interest in the sector, focus on policies and 
programs for basic services, and improve the annual planning and budgeting process. It also 
initiated  support  for  school  management  committees  (SMCs)  and  village  development 
associations (VDAs), and made improvements in governance and aid coordination. However, 
SAP  was  not  an  effective  instrument  to  engage districts  in  social  sector development  and

   3.  Governance Reforms 
 
17.  The lack of access to basic social services of adequate quality is considered a major 
contributing factor to the alarming rise in poverty. The degradation of basic services owes itself 
partly to consistently low levels of investment in the social sector—with per capita spending on 
social sectors in Sindh being the lowest among the four provinces11—and partly on the social 
services management infrastructure, which was highly centralized at the provincial level, out of 
step with local requirements and, for the most part, noninclusive. Lack of appropriate planning 
processes and allocation of resources without evaluating needs and/or financial viability led to a 
large stock of schools, health units, and water supply schemes scattered across the province 
that were abandoned for lack of funds, poor design, or because they were simply not required in 
those areas. In addition, local communities felt no sense of ownership for programs and projects 
designed by international, federal or provincial designed entities. The LGs and local people had 
virtually no say in the development of those sector activities, which were driven by a one-size-
fits-all approach. There was little incentive for local service delivery and accountabilities to 
improve; in fact, LGs strategically withdrew from provision of basic services in education and 
health. Where they were asked to take over provincial schemes, especially in the water sector, 
the LGs failed to maintain them due lack of either finances or sense of ownership.  
 
18.  In August 2001, following a year of local elections, the Government implemented the 
devolution plan and, in one go, created three levels of LGs entailing political, financial, and 
administrative  devolution.  In  Sindh,  it  created  16  DGs,  102  TMAs,  and  1,044  union 
administrations (UAs) to function as autonomous local bodies with their own responsibilities, 
financial shares, and revenue sources.12 DGs were made responsible for schools, colleges, and 
district health services, and TMAs for water supply and waste disposal, in coordination with 
UAs. The Local Government Ordinance (LGO) provides the basic political and administrative 
framework for the devolution. DGs are independent LGs, while TMAs and UAs have been 
designated as autonomous corporate bodies. These new responsibilities require changes in the 
provincial structures for those services and entailed a process of transfer of human and financial 
resources from the province to LGs, as well as a series of amendments in relevant laws, rules, 
systems, procedures, and processes. Given the complexity of the task, it is not surprising that 
the transfer of powers is still continuing. The new mandates clearly posed many new challenges 
for the newly created LGs, which were faced with heightened public expectations on the one 
hand and large capacity gaps to handle these responsibilities, on the other. The new structure 
has shaken up administrative relationships, including placement of the local administration 
under  an elected  council  headed  by  a nazim,13and  relative  autonomy  of  LGs  vis-à-vis  the

19.  Devolution is based on the premise that locally managed basic services will improve 
responsiveness to local needs and facilitate improved delivery, as it provides a range of 
opportunities for enhancing political commitment and greater accountability to the public. During 
the first 2 years after devolution, social sector performance showed signs of improvement, 
although with great variation among districts. Councilors report improvement in staff attendance, 
staff report improved supplies, and several  nazims emphasize the importance of operations 
above new civil works. There are the expected problems—political transfer of staff, and non-
merit-based recruitment of staff and site selection for facilities. The DG budget barely covers the 
expenses for the fixed obligations that were to operate the existing services transferred to them, 
so a general freeze on new construction is required. Salaries have not yet been transferred to 
the district, so DGs have little control over provincial staff and staff transfers. Despite late 
releases of funds and procedural constraints, however, use of available development funds has 
been satisfactory in most places. Much of capacity building has so far concentrated on the DGs, 
while TMAs and UAs have received little attention. Under the Decentralization Support Program 
(DSP) and other external assistance, efforts are under way to improve the capacity of LGs. 
Special efforts are made to improve financial management and the audit trail for tracking 
expenditures. The Accountant General’s office is preparing appropriation accounts for the DGs.  
Steps  initiated  by  SPG  to  address  the  macro  and  microenvironment  issues  are  likely  to 
contribute to the improvement of social sector infrastructure and are in the right direction. 
However, they are clearly not enough as the social and financial gaps are both wide and deep.

  4.  Sector Financing 
 
20.  Education, health, and drinking water and sanitation services collectively made up about 
28% of total provincial spending from FY1999 to FY2003. Between FY2000 and FY2002, 
expenditure  for  education  and  health  increased,  respectively,  11%  and  9%  per  annum. 
However, the share of education and health in total provincial expenditures fell from 24% and 
7% in FY1999 to 20% and 6%, respectively, by FY2003. Nonsalary expenditures accounted for 
a modest 9% of total spending on education and 26% on health, while development spending 
on education and health was 8% in FY2003.  Spending on water and sanitation has been 
minimal due to payment of utility arrears. SPG now commits to maintaining education and 
health spending as a share of provincial revenue, at about 30%, and expects to register growths 
of 12% and 22%, respectively, for education and health in FY2003.  
 
21.  Much of the increase in spending is due to federally decided salary increases. Spending 
on the nonsalary components and on developmental activities in FY2003 was significantly 
below budgetary estimates. In addition, cash flow problems resulted in inadequate and delayed 
releases of funds to the service sites, thereby undermining the proper use of funds to finance 
operations and development. Thus, financing constraints impacted much more seriously on the 
efficiency and effectiveness of service delivery than the overall spending gap would suggest. 
There is a strong case for improving the effective and efficient use of available resources by 
increasing  nonsalary  expenditures.  SPG  has  frozen  new  recruitment,  which  is,  however, 
maintaining the gender imbalance in staffing pattern. SPG also wants to contain infrastructure. 
Further improvement in financing is proposed by increasing the fiscal transfers to provincial

7 
governments  and  LGs,  improving  the  flow  of  funds  to  LGs,  giving  LG  functionaries 
administrative and financial authorities, improving management capacity and procedures, and 
developing partnership with local communities.  
 
22.  The proposed  levels of funding for the education and health sectors are likely to be 
sustainable largely because the overall budget deficits will be much smaller eventually if there 
continues to be a sizable cushion provided by vacant sanctioned positions (which will be partly 
used up by pay rise) and there are timely inflows from other externally assisted programs and 
projects. However, any substantial increase in allocations both in the provincial government and 
DG budgets, so as to move toward MDGs, will be contingent upon accelerated repayment of 
expensive debt and increase in the share of the provinces to at least 40% under the new 
National Finance Commission Award expected to be finalized before the close of FY2004. 
 
  5.  Education 
 
23.  The  National  Education  Sector  Reform  Program  2001  lays  out  education  policies, 
programs, and investment requirements. The major goals are (i) universal primary enrollment 
from about 70% at present; (ii) increase in middle and secondary school enrollments from 
respectively, 48% and 30% to 55% and 40%; (iii) and literacy from 50% to 60% by 2005.14 
Sindh is following this reform program, and is in the process of defining its own targets.  
 
24.  As per the devolution plan, SPG handed over 43,035 schools (and about 200 colleges) 
to DGs, along with the budget to operate and improve services, but excluded salaries and direct 
support to SMCs to improve operation and maintenance of schools.15 About 3 million children 
are currently enrolled in primary school. This number needs to increase by 2 million in the next 
10 years, or 200,000 per year. Consequently, at least another 100,000 children per year should 
be added to classes 6–12 to double current enrollment. Sector trends have started to reverse 
the enrollment decline, with improvements in the quality of instruction and retention of children. 
SPG has provided textbooks and stipends, and improved primary school and teacher salary 
conditions with the support of SAC. In FY2003, however, only about half the targeted number of 
additional children were enrolled in primary schools in Sindh. SPG plans to hire more female 
teachers for primary schools, hire them on contract basis, and make the contract school-specific 
to increase capacity and make schools more attractive for boys and girls.  
 
25.  ADB  has  just  approved  a  Sindh  Decentralized  Elementary  Education  Project  for 
upgrading  1,200  primary  schools  to  elementary  schools.16 SPG  wants  to  further  increase 
support for classes 6–12, including SMCs, adding female teachers, stipends and textbooks. 
SPG is also keen to improve katchi17 classes, shelterless schools, and home schools for literacy 
of girls. The European Commission (EC) is proposing an education project for Sindh in 2005, 
where all the external agencies in the sector will work toward achieving the Sindh education 
program through a sectorwide approach or similar arrangement. The United States Agency for 
International Development (USAID) is directly supporting teacher training and nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs) in 4 districts. Estimates indicate that, considering other aid agency 
commitments, there is a minimal financing gap of PRs3 billion (about $50 million) per year for 
schools up to class 12.

  6.  Health, Nutrition, and Population Welfare 
 
26.  The National Health Policy 2001 and the National Population Policy 2002 describe the 
overall  policy  framework,  programs,  and  investment  requirements  in  the  sector.  SPG  is 
preparing a provincial health strategy with its own revised targets. The child mortality rate is 
expected to drop from 115 to 80 per 1,000 live births over the period 2000-2015, and the 
maternal mortality ratio from about 400 to 250 per 100,000 live births in the same period.  
 
27.  As per the devolution plan, SPG handed over 1,280 of 1,324 health facilities to the 16 
DGs, along with a budget to operate and improve these services, excluding salaries. A major 
problem of basic health facilities is the lack of a minimal budget for operation and maintenance. 
SPG released about 40% of the provincial health budget to the districts to provide primary 
health care ranging from basic health units to district hospitals. The remainder is spent on 44 
provincial institutions and tertiary hospitals. A common view is that hospitals were neglected 
during SAP. However, hospitals are generally in a better state than the basic health facilities 
that lack staff, medicines, and maintenance and repairs. SPG is exploring the possibility of 
making  hospitals  and  teaching  institutions  autonomous  to  improve  their  performance  and 
contain costs. There are no reliable estimates of the funding gap in the provincial and district 
health services. However, minimum international standards for per capita spending on health 
vary between $12 and $75 per year, so a current public spending level of $2 per capita per year 
is in any case very low. The bulk of health sector financing comes from out-of-pocket spending, 
about $9 per person per year. Many poor households can’t afford this, and resort to cheaper 
services of poor quality offered by quacks and shops, and resulting in income erosion. Aside 
from private sector regulation, offering alternative, quality public services is important. Modest 
progress has been made in contracting out services to NGOs. SPG plans to further encourage 
public-private partnership (PPP) in the sector and establish health boards with representation 
from civil society for all health facilities.         
 
28.  About 35% of the health budget is funded through various federal programs. These 
include the expanded program for immunization, the national program for family planning and 
primary health care, the national population program, the nutrition program, and programs for 
the control of tuberculosis, malaria, and the acquired immunodeficiency syndrome. Federal 
programs  are  supported  by  ADB,  Department  for  International  Development  (DFID), 
Government of Japan, United Nations Children’s Fund, United Nations Population Fund, World 
Bank, and other external agencies. The funding gap in these programs for Sindh is estimated at 
PRs1 billion (about $17 million) per year.18 While the delegation of these priority programs to 
DGs is important to strengthen devolution, funding and capacity are major constraints.        
 
  7.  Water and Sanitation

and basic coverage including hand pumps and pit latrines (respectively, 55% and 47%). In total, 
rural areas have 1,056 schemes for water supply and 730 for drainage. About one third of water

   8.  Social Dimensions 
 
32.  Pakistan’s progress in the social sector reflects the local political economy. This situation 
is probably more extreme in Sindh province, which has a major urban-rural political divide and a 
feudal/tribal system largely intact in rural areas. Private services in rural areas are very few, 
unlike in the cities and towns, where there is a well-developed private sector. The private sector 
has a strong spirit of entrepreneurship, philanthropy, and self-regulation, as is evident in the 
numerous nonprofit organizations, self-sustaining schools and hospitals, and other services for 
the poor. Without these, the social status in Sindh would have been much worse today. These 
urban services are mostly institutionalized, and are often operated by families and social 
groups. In contrast, local initiatives in rural areas often depend on individual leadership for 
survival.  This  leadership  at  the  village  level  can,  however,  have  a  major  impact.  Due  to 
differences in local leadership, two economically comparable villages can greatly differ in social 
indicators, which may reflect on the status of women, community support mechanisms, and 
village hygiene. A common problem is that communities lack confidence and know-how to take 
control of their social services. However, the transition process is well under way in many 
communities where SMCs are now managing and improving schools. In Khairpur district, health 
boards operate government health facilities. About one quarter of water schemes are operated 
through community-owned, self-regulated VDAs. To capture these developments, a favorable 
governance  and  financial  environment  is  necessary,  as  well  as  local,  hands-on  capacity 
building. Indeed, given the political economy of Pakistan, the Government cannot be expected 
to operate social services effectively without strong community support. For a highly centralized 
Government focusing on its own processes of control and audit, this is a major challenge. 
Devolution provides the opportunity to take bold steps toward community owned social services.   
 
33.  The traditional roles of men and women are deeply ingrained in Sindh’s rural society. For 
their own security and the welfare of their children, women have internalized a submissive role 
since  childhood.  Devolution  has  addressed  gender  issues  to  some  extent,  including  the 
reservation of one third of reserve seats for female councilors. In practice, however, women 
have little voice except in positions of high authority. Many external agencies provide multiple 
training programs for women leaders, but mostly without adjusting structural impediments and

10    
mobilizing public support. Major gender reforms are planned under the Gender Reform Action 
Plan (GRAP) supported by ADB and other agencies.  
     
B.  Issues and Opportunities 
 
34.  Multiple Problems and Pervasive Poverty. Sindh’s many problems combined with 
pervasive  poverty  are  potentially  overwhelming  government  and  private  resources.  The 
technology for developing basic services in all sectors is more or less standard and available. 
The policies and reform agendas for the education and health sectors are basically sound, while 
those for the water and sanitation sector need to be developed. The social sectors are dissimilar 
in many respects but the major problems affecting them are comparable. While problems can’t 
be  linked  to  a  single  cause,  nor  addressed  in  an  isolated  manner,  governance,  and  the 
underlying  political  economy are at the core of the problems. Social sector development, 
foremost,  requires  governance  reforms.  Poverty  reduction,  including  social  development, 
requires  a  coordinated  governance  response  to  improve  social  sector  management  and 
financing under the overall umbrella of the PRSP, the Sindh Reform Program, and the LGO. 
The sectors have improved following devolution, but further governance reforms are needed.   
   
35.  Slow Pace of Transfer of Powers. While it is clear that the responsibility for providing 
basic services in health, education, and water and sanitation have been assigned to the LGs, 
commensurate administrative authority has not yet been fully devolved. For example, public 
health  engineering  staff  has  been  posted  to  districts  rather  than  to  TMAs.  Roles  and 
responsibilities  of  line  departments  and  LGs  lack  clarity.  Areas  such  as  recruitment, 
procurement, and intergovernmental relations in terms of monitoring responsibilities are still all 
fairly fluid and there are still no systems for establishing linkages among the LGs themselves. 
Also, personnel management is not yet devolved. The provincial government continues to 
exercise administrative powers over the transfers and postings of officers. This setup seriously 
hampers the ability of the LGs to rationalize and redeploy staff, enforce work discipline and hold 
staff accountable for performance. Moreover, LGs lack financial control. Devolution of political 
power must be followed by a process of gradual fiscal decentralization, which can only be 
actualized after fiscal powers have been transferred to the LGs.  
 
36.  Poorly Distributed Services and Shortage of Resources.  LGs need to rationalize 
services. New infrastructure is not matched with a budget to run the services. This imbalance 
may further increase unless services are rationally planned. Staff is poorly distributed across 
Sindh due to harsh living conditions. In particular, attention should be given to lack of access to 
services for the very poor, women and girls, and people living in remote hamlets. In the 
education and health sectors, there is a major problem of shortage of female staff in rural areas. 
In the health sector, there are also major imbalances among the various cadres. In the water 
and sanitation sector (WSS), there is lack of trained engineers at TMA level. Alternative 
strategies  of  service  delivery  have  to  be  deployed  to  make  services  available  to  rural 
populations, such as the recruitment of local women, provision of home schools for girls, and 
incentives and security arrangements. Social sector financing also needs improvement. SPG 
financing is not pro-poor and needs improvement in terms of allocation, flow of funds, financial 
management, accountability, and transparency. The provinces in Pakistan have a very narrow 
tax base. As a result, they depend heavily on transfers from the federal Government. In the 
case of Sindh, federal transfers account for 75% of the total resources available to SPG. 
Because  these  transfers  are  either  irregular  or  incomplete,  they  cause SPG considerable 
problems in cash flow management. Consequently, resource flows to the LGs—whose own 
revenue base is very limited and which in turn depend on provincial transfer—are unpredictable, 
thereby preventing LGs from effectively planning and implementing development initiatives.

11 
 
37.  Reluctance  of  Local  Governments  to  Involve  Communities.  The  Sindh  LGO 
envisages and encourages partnerships between the LGs and civil society. However, the 
performance of citizens community boards in Sindh is poor. Similarly, in the case of schools, 
where the forum of SMCs has been strengthened, and the VDAs in the water sector to whom 
schemes are handed over for management after completion, there is a clear tilt toward involving 
the community in various modes of engagement (coproducers, oversight roles, etc.). However, 
a more concerted attempt to achieve these partnerships is needed.  
 
38.  Limited Managerial and Technical Capacity. A concerted, cohesive, organized yet 
multipronged approach is needed to build the capacity of LGs to levels that will enable them to 
deliver basic services. The Government has already initiated the DSP, aimed at strengthening 
the LGs by developing their capacities in basic areas such as audit, accounts, budgeting, and 
communication. Major efforts are needed to improve the managerial and technical skills of staff 
working in the social sector. The DSP will be working closely with the DSSP and the Access to 
Justice Program, and the 3 programs will complement each other. 
 
39.  One-Time Opportunity for Major Governance Reforms with Devolution. The social 
sector employs more than half of Sindh’s civil servants. This is a one-time opportunity to reform 
the social sector, which so far received limited support in the devolution process. The transition 
provides an important opportunity to mobilize civil society, introduce participatory approaches, 
promote public-private partnership, and develop a new role for the PLDs.  
 
40.  Political Will, Local Leaders, and Participation to Achieve MDGs. Vested interests 
are opposed to devolution and may cause political instability and lack of commitment. Priorities 
of politicians may be in conflict with those that service the public interest best. Coordination with 
the DSP and other programs gives opportunities to educate and groom new leaders, and 
develop local institutions. The public needs to be informed about expectations from and the 
performance of local leaders on such topics as public needs and rights, and the quality and 
distribution of services. Community-based organizations (CBOs) can be made responsible for 
routine services, as has been shown in the education sector. The proximity of beneficiaries 
offers a major opportunity to improve transparency, quality, and accountability of services on a 
sustainable basis. While this is a sensitive issue for LGs who have just assumed power, reforms 
may be relatively easier now before the current system becomes entrenched. The private sector 
is growing rapidly in the urban sector. It is the leading provider in the health sector and will, in 
the years ahead, operate about half the schools in Sindh. SPG has been exploring partnership 
and is keen to set up a fund to sponsor NGOs proposed by LGs to support CBOs and improve 
social services, e.g., through contracting out entire services or contracting in managers. At the 
same time, the private sector also needs support to become more effective in quality of 
services, possibly with the help of self-regulatory mechanisms.    
 
41.  Sindh’s social sector indicators show high levels of illiteracy, malnutrition, mortality and 
population growth, which have a major impact on Sindh’s economy, environment, and water 
resources.  Public  social  services  are  run-down  due  to  chronic  problems  in  governance, 
capacity, and financing. The current public sector is by and large an employment scheme, 
spending almost exclusively on salaries with hardly any budget to operationalize services. 
Development spending has also declined to an all-time low. The Government is committed to 
address the poverty trap and gender imbalance in a holistic manner including the development 
of  social  services.  It  is  evident  that  improving  of  efficiency,  equity,  effectiveness,  and 
sustainability in the social sector requires addressing the  serious problems in governance,

12    
participation, and financing. Otherwise, it is unlikely that social indicators will move toward the 
MDGs.  
  
42.  The SPG is committed to reduce poverty through economic, social, legal and political 
dimensions of governance by forging partnerships with civil society including PPPs. SPG has 
developed a comprehensive approach to uplift public and community services for the poor, 
based on a medium-term framework to improve key MDG indicators. In 2003, SPG prepared the 
Sindh PRSP. The Sindh Reform Program and the Sindh LGO provide the basic financial and 
governance framework for social sector development. Sector reform programs have also been 
formulated based on the National Education Sector Reform Program and the National Health 
Policy. Uniform policies for the WSS will be adapted to the new role of TMAs in the devolved 
setup.  
 
43.  The Sindh PRSP proposes a three-pronged poverty reduction strategy focusing on (i) 
equitable delivery of social services to the poor, (ii) creation of employment opportunities for the 
poor, and (iii) provision of an institutional arrangement for skills transfer and extension of micro 
credit  to  the  poor.  In  the  social  sector,  it  aims  to  improve  performance  through  better 
governance, stronger partnership with civil society, and need-based allocation of resources. 
SPG requested ADB to provide support for a DSSP. ADB’s Country Strategy and Program 
(2002–2006) fully endorses Sindh’s focus on poverty reduction, with governance as the central 
pillar. ADB’s major thrusts are (i) good governance including decentralization and access to 
justice, (ii) pro-poor economic growth, and (iii) inclusive social development. The Program gives 
substantial emphasis on participation: citizen involvement, especially of women, and private 
sector development. It also renews emphasis on water resource management. 
 
44.  The Sindh Reform Program aims to address governance and fiscal reforms as the root 
causes of poverty and deprivation. The World Bank’s SAC supports  the provincial effort to 
improve financing and administration, and to pursue civil service reforms. SPG has already 
undertaken a number of initiatives ranging from increasing the budget outlays on health and 
education in recent years, embarking upon broad governance reforms, and support for general 
capacity building for LGs. For example, the allocations for maintenance and rehabilitation in the 
WSS increased by 58% in FY2003 and by 21% in FY2004. The proposed DSSP’s support for 
reform and financing builds on the SAC inputs.     
 
45.  The Sindh LGO offers major opportunities for social sector reforms. The LGs give a level 
of political representation that is closer to and more dependent on public interests. However, 
there are major challenges and risks. Local leaders have just taken control, have limited 
exposure to working with other stakeholders in the social sector, and may not be ready to share 
powers. LGs are ill equipped to undertake reforms, particularly in the social sector, and risk 
repeating previous mistakes due to lack of technology transfer. Misuse of funds for projects 
selected not on the basis of merit is a real risk. To increase accountability, the LGO emphasizes 
strengthening the role of the community, particularly through CBOs, and citizen oversight 
arrangements. It also favors expanding social services through PPP and the private sector. This 
links well with the realities on the ground, where communities and the private sector (including

47.  Based on lessons learned during SAP, and the changed relationship with LGs after

IV.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
A.  Objectives and Scope

water and sanitation, and thus help reduce poverty and gender imbalances. The broad purpose 
is to increase school enrolment, and coverage with health and clear water and sanitation 
services. These objectives are to be achieved by improving governance and financing of social 
services, that should in turn result in increased access to basic social services, in particular for 
women, better quality of services, and improved efficiency, affordability, and sustainability of 
services. The program framework is in Appendix 1, and overall sector targets are in Appendix 2.

50.  The Program has five principal policy outcomes: (i) further devolve social services to

51.  Program support will comprise a conditional block grant support to LGs to undertake 
social sector development according to local priorities within the defined program scope. This 
flexibility, combined with local planning, ensures that funding for programs and projects will not 
overlap. In education, the program covers all schools, ranging from katchi class to class 10, or 
class 12 for a few higher secondary schools, but not colleges.22 In health, the scope ranges 
from community health workers to district hospitals. In WSS, within the authority of TMAs, it 
includes surveys and mapping, rehabilitation of mechanized schemes that are considered

The Program also supports crosscutting activities such as women’s development, advocacy, 
and leadership training. LGs will prepare annual sector plans to access funding. LGs will decide 
on  the  priorities  but  the  plans  should  reflect  a  minimum  package  of  interventions  to  be 
undertaken from all available resources (including other external assistance) and adhere to 
certain items that cannot be financed from program proceeds, or only on certain conditions.    
 
52.  The DSSP will provide program support for province-wide devolved social services for 3 
years, and project support for a TA for strengthening social sector development for 4 years.  
 
53.  The TA project supports (i) sector and program management and monitoring, (ii) LG 
capacity building and partnership development, and (iii) sector specific policy reforms. Further 
TA through a separate TA for international consulting services is planned for 2004 (para. 105).   
 
54.  The DSSP supports the Sindh PRSP, the Sindh Reform Program, and the Sindh LGO. 
The Program will be specifically linked to the SAC, especially on fiscal restructuring and civil

Justice Program, especially on governance reforms, devolution of powers, and administrative

coordinated  with  and  supplementary  to  other  external  assistance.  The  development 
coordination matrix is in Appendix 3.     
 
55.    The recently established LGs are to uplift the run-down social services, rationalize them 
and make them more sustainable. The LGs face major constraints: limited capacity, continuing 
control exercised by the province, lack of clarity on the role of the districts and the line 
departments, lack of financial autonomy, lack of integration of federal programs, inability or 
unwillingness to enter into a regular partnership with communities, and political, economic and 
social  constraints.  Policy  reforms  are  needed  in  financing,  transfer  and  use  of  funds, 
governance procedures, and community participation and responsiveness. 
 
56.    Uplifting social services first of all requires action to improve the flow of funds to LGs, 
which have continued to be affected by fiscal constraints. Arrangements need to be put in place 
that assure more consistent funding and timely release of funds to LGs. Second, planning and 
implementation capacity needs to be strengthened to be able to use funds properly.

57.    As elected LGs receive delegated powers, they urgently need assistance to develop a 
more  systematic  approach  in  operating  services  in  their  areas  of  jurisdiction.  There  is  a 
substantial risk that management will be ad hoc and focused on new facilities, neglecting the 
operation  of  existing  services.  Three  elements  are  needed.  First,  through  a  consultative

needs. Second, the priorities need to be reflected in the financing and expenditure plans. Third, 
an important but sensitive area is to undertake consensus building with local stakeholders to 
decide on the future of nonfunctioning schemes and take action accordingly. Similarly, a plan 
and process should be put in place to improve staff balance through adjustments in training, 
positions, postings, and retrenchment. These actions need to be preceded by documentation of 
facilities  and  staff,  performance  and  needs  assessment,  and  consultation  of  potential 
beneficiaries and local leaders. 
 
58.    Making services more sustainable requires further support and development of local 
institutions to develop greater local autonomy in operating services based on the principles of 
partnership. Communities have to take an active role in improving service delivery through local 
institutions. SMCs need to be further institutionalized to operate schools, and expanded to 
include secondary schools. VDAs or private sector arrangements need to be developed to 
manage water schemes. SMCs and VDAs need capacity building to develop and implement 
plans, and communities need to understand their role in supporting the SMC and VDAs in 
providing services. The health sector, by the nature of its business, is more complicated, but 
also offer opportunities to establish and strengthen patient associations and health boards, and 
gradually make health services more autonomous, self-sufficient, and accountable, and thus 
raise standards of health service delivery and mobilize other sources of financing.    
 
59.  Funding can be targeted to an area already supported by other sources to supplement 
existing allocations, or it can be devoted to filling an investment gap, for example, by providing 
critical infrastructure facilities missing in functional schools or by supporting the extension of the 
scope of the government’s existing program for providing stipends to include girls enrolled in 
secondary grades (9–10), thereby addressing the issue of gender disparity and improving 
retention rates among girls. A similar flexible approach will be used in the other sectors. DGs 
will be allowed to balance funding between the education and health sectors, and TMAs within 
the water and sanitation subsectors.   
 
60.  For example, program funds can finance the provision of essential infrastructure lacking 
in primary and middle schools, e.g., additional classrooms, boundary walls, toilets, drinking 
water supply, furniture, etc. This support will be available if DGs can inventory the existing 
infrastructure in schools under their jurisdiction and identify for each school the basic facilities 
required. Infrastructural improvement that will be allowed should make the school operational, to 
ensure that all new schools will be functioning. 
 
61.  Since program funding will be targeted to specific areas or items from a specific positive 
list, a system of conditional grants will be set up tying availability of funds to the fulfillment of 
certain conditions, with performance to be judged on the basis of outcomes (like a 6 percentage 
point increase in participation and completion rates by gender) in the medium to long term, 
outputs (like enrollment levels consistent with the targeted participation rates in the short term), 
or performance with respect to process indicators (like share of education in total expenditure, 
spending on nonsalary items as a proportion of the expenditure on education, timely release 
and use of funds, and number of schools completed through provision of facilities). To ensure 
that the funds provided are used for the expressed purposes, SPG will enter into contractual 
agreements that define the rules of engagement between the respective LGs and SPG.

62.  Since the DGs and TMAs will be the implementing agencies for the bulk of the proposed 
reforms  and  interventions,  the  program  design  proposes  a  strengthening  of  the  financial

C.  Important Features 
 
84.  Given past experiences, the importance of supporting governance reforms in devolved 
social services cannot be underestimated. The DSSP is primarily a governance program that 
aims to build local responsibility and capacity to undertake effective planning and efficient 
execution of demand-driven plans to address prioritized needs in the social sector. Technical 
approaches are more or less based on international standards, but may slightly vary from place 
to place according to local circumstances, technical capacity, and funds.    
 
85.  The Program has four important features:  
 
(i)  The Program provides for an enabling environment by creating fiscal space, 
adequate and timely flow of funds, policy support, and linkages in the social 
sector. It provides for an innovative fund flow mechanism by channeling program 
funds directly to LGs through Account IV.  
 
(ii)  The  Program  offers  flexible  financial  and  technical  support  to  the  LGs  for 
adopting more effective, demand-driven, and participatory planning processes to 
identify gaps, and rationalize and develop services. 
 
(iii)  At this early stage of LG, the Program pushes community participation and 
partnership with NGOs. While it may be argued that this step may be premature, 
it occurs at a time of transition when routine has not yet been established, and 
gives the opportunity to strengthen the roles of the community and NGOs.  
 
(iv)  In  addition  to  the  built-in  synergies  available  from  the  TA  component,  the 
Program provides for establishing linkages with a number of ongoing initiatives 
aimed at supporting the decentralized system. Foremost among these is the 
DSP, which is a program for building the capacity of LGs in basic areas such as 
accounting, budgeting, and auditing as well as supporting the development of 
new institutions in the field of governance. The DSSP will be implemented in 
close coordination with the DSP to ensure complementarity of efforts. In fact, 
some outcomes of the DSSP will ride on the successful outcomes of both the 
DSP and SAC, the broad-based macro reforms agenda sponsored by the World 
Bank. In the case of the DSP, successful implementation of the capacity-building 
initiatives in budgeting will, for example, enable the DSSP to add more specific 
budgeting and performance orientation techniques, while the civil service reforms 
and fiscal discipline that SAC seeks to develop will provide a more enabling 
environment for the DSSP components.

V.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  
 
A.  Objectives 
 
105.  The TA aims to (i) strengthen sector and program management and monitoring, (ii) 
develop LGs and CBO governance capacity in social services, and (iii) support sector work on 
specific policy reforms to improve sector performance. This includes support to strengthen 
linkages and cooperation between stakeholders, establish proper accounting practices, and 
monitoring and evaluation of sector financing and performance. 
  
B.  Components and Output 
1.  Program and Sector Management and Monitoring  
106.  The TA will support the PSU and LSUs to ensure that all initiatives envisioned under the 
DSSP are carried out as per the agreed-upon Policy matrix. The PSU will be responsible for 
program monitoring and TA implementation. The PSU and LSUs will collaborate with LGs to 
track sector financing and monitor financial management. The PSU will also monitor and 
evaluate sector performance using existing management information systems, improve these as 
appropriate, and work with other agencies conducting surveys.  
 
  2.  Governance Capacity Building  
 
107.  The TA will support capacity building for the social sectors, initially through PSU and 
LSUs, but also through provincial training institutions, thereby supplementing efforts undertaken 
by the DSP and SAC, and efforts to be undertaken by EC and USAID in education. The PSU 
will organize awareness campaigns about the poverty reduction strategy and devolved social 
services. LSUs will strengthen LGs in the areas of annual planning and budgeting for social 
services  using  a  participatory  approach,  gender  mainstreaming,  sector  management  and 
monitoring, financial management as required, strengthening linkages of governments and 
communities, and capacity building of CBOs including SMCs, health boards and VDAs. The TA 
may also support NGOs to prepare them for capacity building of CBOs or special services.

  3.  Sector-Specific Reforms 
 
108.  PLDs will be assisted to examine a range of policy issues in the social sector and work 
on specific policy reforms. In education, this includes the functioning of SMCs, contracting 
teachers, and affordability of education.  In the health sector, the critical activity is to establish 
health boards and patients associations to strengthen local participation in managing services. 
Studies  will  examine  contracting  arrangements  for  staff  and  PPP, improving the financial 
sustainability of health facilities, and rationalizing and operationalizing closed health facilities. In 
the WSS, technical support will support monitoring systems, categorizing schemes, consumer 
surveys, and preparing master plans for TMAs. Based on studies and using a  participatory 
process, interim policies for the sector will be prepared, including policies for drinking water 
supply, and solid waste management in general and health facilities in particular.

VI.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Program Benefits   
 
119.  Social Sector Financing.  The DSSP will result in an increased budget for the social 
sector, a new funding mechanism for devolved social services, and better cash flow. Qualifying 
SMCs, health boards and water associations will be financed directly. SPG will also give grants 
to NGOs to build the capacity of CBOs and other activities. Water charges will be rationalized to 
make them more pro-poor and consumption-driven in the case of water.        
 
120.  Participatory Planning. The DSSP will increase capabilities and the participation of 
common and special councilors in decision-making bodies in DGs, TMAs, and UAs. Special 
attention will be given to the participation of female councilors. Efforts will be made to ensure 
adequate representation of civil society and NGOs in district planning activities. Mechanisms will 
be  set  up  to  clarify  responsibilities  and  thus  improve  collaboration  among  political 
representatives and bureaucrats and improve coordination of development activities.       
 
121.  Rationalization of Services.  The TA will provide major support for building the capacity 
of DGs, TMAs, UAs, and CBOs to undertake proper planning, implementation, and monitoring 
and thus ensure efficient, equitable, and effective use of limited resources. Each district, and in 
the case of the water sector, each TMA will directly be supported by experts who will provide 
hands-on experience in this field.       
 
122.  Community Organizations. SPG will use the TA fund to build the capacity of CBOs, 
SMCs, health boards, and VDAs, to qualify them as recipients of SPG financing to improve local 
social  services.  Qualifying  organizations  will  eventually  be  allowed  to  operate  their  own 
services, including contracting of staff. Such community organization will also benefit other 
sectors and overall improve devolution and governance in the public sector.       
 
B.  Impacts   
 
1.  Social Sector Impact 
 
123.  The Program will result in higher school participation and completion rates, especially of 
girls, due to (i) better access to schools for village children, (ii) contracting of female teachers, 
(iii) better school conditions, and (iv) more affordable secondary schools. Similarly, improved 
access to female health staff and field workers, will improve reproductive health, and reduce 
maternal  mortality,  and  curb  fertility  through  noninvasive  methods.  The improvement and 
reopening of schools and clinics and provision of accessible clean drinking water will have a 
major impact on the social status of the population. The currently sourced water is generally 
unfit for human consumption and carries the risk of waterborne diseases. Poor-quality water is 
responsible for high levels of infant mortality, while high levels of morbidity cause frequent 
school absenteeism in children and loss of workdays for adults. The availability of basic services 
and clean water will create better living conditions for the people and will enhance their 
productivity levels. SPG aims to increase gross primary enrollment from 65% to 80%, increase

27 
rural access to safe drinking water from 24 % to 30%, increase full immunization coverage of 
children from 50% to 85%, and reduce infant mortality from 80 to 70 per 1,000 live births.    
     
  2.  Poverty and Gender Impact 
 
124.  Support for social services, devolution, and community participation and organization will 
have a positive impact on the poor. Funding, access, and quality of social services are all 
expected to improve. More chiIdren will go to school, and receive better-quality education, which 
will have an impact on the entire family. Better health care should also reduce income erosion 
and improve productivity. The Program is targeting all districts in Sindh by supporting public 
social services used mostly by the poor. The majority of the beneficiaries are likely to be poor. 
The summary poverty impact of policy actions is in Appendix 11.    
 
125.  Female councilors will be assisted to learn how to participate in council meetings and 
planning activities. Many LGs and CBOs are keen to hire female teachers and paramedics, and 
improve schools, and health and water and sanitation services that will particularly benefit girls. 
The Program’s impact will be monitored through surveys, including equity indicators.   
 
126.  The Program and TA activities are intended to improve governance in the social sector. 
The result should be more pro-poor allocation and more efficient use of resources. Improved 
governance also involves disciplinary actions against poorly performing staff. Retrenchment of 
some staff can be expected, with a possible adverse impact on their families. Currently, water 
charges are deducted at source, and are invisible for some who do not pay any charges. The 
practice, however, often results in poor services and waste of funds that could be used for other 
services.  Overall,  the  price  of  water  services  is  expected  to  fall  and  be  linked  to  actual 
consumption. The water experts will carry out a consumer survey and participator planning 
process to assess the implications of proposed pricing reforms on the poor and how they can be 
addressed. The summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 12. 
 
        3.  Financial and Economic Impacts 
 
127.  SPG is increasing social sector spending under the PRSP to achieve its social sector 
goals. The DSSP requires SPG to approve additional funds for the social sector, improve cash 
flow, and provide up-front financing. The program costs to the Government are $45 million 
higher than the size of the program loans during the program period. SPG hopes to finance the 
costs through debt reduction and a tax increase averaging 15% per year. It is believed that the 
economic returns from better education, health, and drinking water nearby will outweigh the 
costs of the tax increase. With infrastructure and salaries already paid for, a modest increase in 
targeted spending for quality enhancing actions will greatly improve use and efficiency.  
 
4.  Institutional Impact  
 
128.  The Program will contribute to the overall devolution reform process. Foremost, it will 
strengthen LGs to contribute to one of the largest institutional transition in Pakistan. It is 
expected to have a major impact on governance in the social sector and will help create a 
favorable environment for improved transparency and accountability, empowerment of common 
citizens, and the rule of law. The Program will particularly help strengthen and increase the 
number of CBOs—including SMCs, health boards, and VDAs. Through opportunities for PPP, 
the Program will also strengthen local NGOs, and thereby help to expand the private sector.

28    
  5.  Environmental Aspects    
 
129.  The DSSP is classified as environmental category B. Apart from hospital and health 
center wastes, and  water supply, sanitation and garbage collection, no major environmental 
hazards are anticipated. The Environmental Protection Agency of SPG and the PSU, supported 
by a consultant, will prepare environmental plans for managing hospital and health center 
wastes and for other types of facilities and operations. They will ensure that environmental 
measures are included in upgrading the operations of district health agencies and other types of 
services to avoid significant environmental impacts. The environmental assessment summary 
including an assessment of the policy actions and an environmental management plan are in 
Supplementary Appendix D.   
 
C.  Risks 
 
  1.  Political Risks 
 
130.  Sindh’s political instability, and therefore sustained commitment to the  devolution and 
governance reform agenda, is considered a major risk for the Program. There are dissenting 
voices among provincial stakeholders. Major issues in Sindh are the sharp urban-rural divide, 
and resistance of those in control to giving up old privileges. That majority of the elected council 
heads and deputy heads are from landed families highlights the danger of capture of DGs by 
local  elites,  and  subsequent  continuation  of  privileges.  While  there  are  early  signs  of 
improvement, the conceptual framework of structural changes leading to greater accountability 
at the local level still needs to be demonstrated. Much exchange of ideas and clarification will be 
needed to ensure political support at all levels and put a transparent and fair system in place.  
 
  2.  Economic and Financial Risks   
 
131.  The economic and financial risks are considered less prominent.  There are sector 
financing risks linked to the economy, as was experienced during the SAP, which was seriously 
affected by the fiscal crisis of the 1990s. Continuing lack of funds resulted in staff shortages and 
lack  of  nonsalary  recurrent  allocations  that  undermined  the  services.  The  current 
macroeconomic picture looks much better given Pakistan’s overall international and economic 
performance  in  the  past  few  years,  a  healthy  budget  surplus,  fair  economic  growth,  and 
expected  reduction  of  debt  to  4.5%  of  GDP  in  FY2003  and  4.0%  in  FY2004.  However, 
continuing economic growth will  depend on a benign external environment for debt servicing 
and investment, which is tied to the political situation in Pakistan. Furthermore, the drought of 
the past few years demonstrated Pakistan’s dependency on ecological conditions and the water 
resource management systems. The resulting increase in rural poverty is believed to have had 
a major negative impact on school enrollment. The serious levels of poverty in rural areas and 
urban slums, in combination with social inequity, pose major program constraints.                     
 
  3.  Capacity Constraints   
  
132.  The  federal  Government  decided  to  opt  for  fast-track  devolution  with  remarkable 
political, administrative, and fiscal restructuring; development of new systems and guidelines; 
and training of administrators and councilors, all within the span of 1 year. However, the 
devolved system still needs to be fully operationalized and PLDs should provide full support. A 
major concern is the limited capacity of the LGs and CBOs. Major capacity-building efforts that 
will benefit the social sector are underway, but specific support for capacity building in the 
devolved social sector is largely lacking. In particular the capacity of CBOs is of concern.

5.  School Management Committees. Establishing SMCs has been the major initiative 
for improving schools. About 33% have received grants from the Government, and 25% 
have been able to mobilize additional funds from their respective communities. As the funds 
are linked to the number of classrooms, Government grants are biased against shelterless 
schools. In many SMCs, the head teacher usually decides  how the Government grants 
should be used, rather than encouraging parents to participate in decision making. Most 
councils find the list of eligible expenditure categories too narrow and rigid and demand 
greater flexibility in the use of funds.        
   
6.  Facilities. School buildings are generally poor in rural areas compared with those in 
urban areas and private schools. Of the 15,000 shelterless schools in rural areas, about 
3,100 are being upgraded with World Bank assistance. Many schools in urban areas are 
overcrowded, with children sitting on the veranda, under the trees, and on the roof. The 
easier way to increase school enrollment is no doubt adding classrooms in urban areas, as 
demand is high and teachers are in surplus. Lack of amenities, furniture, and maintenance 
are  problems  affecting  most  government  schools.  The  supply  of  textbooks  to  primary 
schools has improved with external assistance, and could be expanded to higher grades.  
   
7.  Human Resources. Even if 33–40% of posts were vacant, a ban on recruitment was 
maintained  during  Social  Action  Program  (Sector)  Project  II,  as  part  of  public  sector 
rationalization. This was expected to deal with surplus teachers. However, due to politics, 
poor rural working conditions, and lack of incentives, redeployment has not been successful. 
Irregular transfer practices continue. The Government is now planning to introduce a policy 
of  exclusive  female  teachers  for  primary  schools,  so  as  to  make  coeducation  more 
accessible to girls. Hiring of teachers on contract basis and from the community should also 
help in reducing staff absenteeism. However, there is no evidence to suggest that locally 
hired teachers, including for private schools, perform better. Supervision, monitoring, and 
disciplinary action are also needed.   
 
8.  Quality of Education. Primary instruction is notoriously poor (parrot method) and 
has probably deteriorated. Many teachers are untrained. The Government is now following a 
policy of hiring matriculate graduates as teachers and training them through in-service 
training, rather than preservice training. However, the performance of trained teachers is not 
much better, for a variety of reasons. Enrollment data are misleading, as attendance is 
usually much lower. Monitoring of pupil and teacher attendance is a priority. The curriculum 
and examination system need to be updated (this is a federal responsibility).

9.  Financing. Education up to class 10 has been made free in Government schools. 
Under the World Bank’s structural adjustment credit, the budget for education has increased. 
In 2002–2003, PRs19.9 billion was allocated for education: PRs16.5 billion for salaries, 
PRs1.6 billion  for nonsalary recurrent expenditures, and PRs1.6 billion for development 
expenditures. The budget for primary school SMCs increased from PRs1.1 billion in 2001–
2002 to PRs4.5 billion in 2002–2003, on the basis of PRs167 per child per year for use on a 
need basis. This does not include support for katchi class, shelterless schools, and class 6 
upward. PRs180 million was spent to distribute free textbooks to students of all primary 
schools, and PRs270 million on scholarships for girl students of middle schools (classes 6–
8) at PRs100 per child per month. PRs50 million from the regular budget of 2002–2003 is 
allocated to districts for teacher training.   
 
10.  Policy. The  National Policy of Education, 1998–2010, aims for universal primary 
education with 100% net participation, quality and functionality in the secondary stage with 
participation  increased  to  50%,  greater  emphasis  on  rural  female  education,  and 
improvement in quality to meet the demands of the job market by 2004. Targets continue to 
be high, such as increasing net enrolment rate from 65% in 2001 to 75% in 2004, and 
increasing literacy from 47% to 60% in the same period. For a holistic approach to education 
a sector-wide strategy entailing legislative, administrative, and financial actions at all levels 
has been adopted.2 The Education Sector Reforms for 2001–2004, a 3-year action plan to 
implement  the  policy,  includes  Literacy  through  Education  for  All  supported  by  the 
Compulsory Primary Education Ordinance. It includes resource mobilization including debt 
swap for education, decentralization under the devolution plan, public-private partnership 
and community participation. Its actions include generating political will, mainstreaming 
madrassahs,3 introducing  outcome-based  planning  and  budgeting,  and  demand-based 
education.   
 
11.  Priority investments are (i) support for SMCs ($20 million), (ii) construction of 3,000 
shelterless schools ($30 million), (iii) reopening of 5,000 closed schools ($5 million), (iv) 
upgrading primary schools to elementary schools ($150 million), (v) change of 1,000 schools 
to English medium ($10 million), and (vi) upgrading of middle school to secondary school 
($150 million per school). In- service teacher training is earmarked for major grant financing.        
 
B.  Health, Nutrition, and Population Sector 
 
12.  Status. Sindh’s important health indices are not good. Infant and child mortality rates 
per  1,000  live  births  are  85  and  103,  respectively,  in  particular  due  to  diarrhea  and 
respiratory infections. About 40% of children under the age of 5 years are malnourished. 
One quarter of children are born with low birth weight. Drug-resistant tuberculosis and 
malaria are common. The number of maternal deaths has declined due to a reduction in 
fertility. The total fertility rate has dropped from around 6.3 to 4.7 in 15 years, due to late 
marriages and modern family planning practiced by 27% of married couples. However, the 
risk of dying during pregnancy has not declined much. The maternal mortality ratio has 
remained  at  about  350  maternal  deaths  per  100,000  live  births.  Sindh  is  also  facing 
increasing prevalence of noncommunicable diseases. About 50% of the disease burden is 
accounted for by non-communicable diseases, 38% by communicable diseases, and 12% by 
maternal and prenatal conditions. The prevalence of noncommunicable diseases is expected 
to increase to 70% by 2020, and increase the demand for costly interventions in chronic 
conditions.
