13.  Services. Coverage and output indicators show the shortcomings of service delivery. 
Full immunization coverage of infants is 50%. Less than 40% of women deliver in health 
facilities, and less than 38% of them receive skilled assistance during delivery. Availability of 
24-hour basic and comprehensive emergency obstetric care in public sector facilities is 
estimated at 15% and 25%, respectively. Health services are an inequitable mixture of a 
fairly large network of run-down public services; high-technology, expensive private sector 
care; private practitioners; traditional healers; and shops and quacks. Provincial public health 
services are extended through 1,324 facilities comprising 36 major hospitals, 73 district and 
subdistrict hospitals, 98 rural health centers, 724 basic health units, 274 dispensaries, and 
119 other categories of facilities. The bed population ratio is 1:1,251. Following devolution, 
about 400 facilities of defunct metropolitan and municipal corporations have been added. In 
addition, the federal Government runs vertical programs for immunization, tuberculosis, 
malaria, HIV/AIDS4 control, nutrition, population welfare; and the national program for family 
planning and primary health care supporting lady health workers. The lady health workers 
reach about one quarter of the poor, and provide basic care for women and children. ADB’s  
Women’s Health Project supports four district governments to improve obstetric services and 
generally make communities and services more responsive to the health needs of women.  
 
14.  Financing. The health sector received 5–7% of the total provincial program of Sindh 
in the postdevolution years (FY2002 and FY2003). Districts received about 43% of the 
budget in FY2003 (although salaries were retained at provincial levels). The provincial share 
of the annual development program increased from 41% in FY2002 to 63% in FY2003. In 
FY2003, of 83% PRs535 million was allocated to 5 medical colleges and 17% to 35 schools 
and  centers  for  paramedical,  nursing,  and  in-service training. The same year, tertiary 
hospitals were allocated 25% of the nondevelopment budget. Preventive health programs 
and foreign aided programs budgeted at PRs1.4 billion are linked to federal programs. The 
counterpart  budgets  of  these  federal  programs  are  allocated  about  one  third  of  the 
development budget while the remaining is spent mostly on civil works. As a result, primary 
care is seriously underfunded. Free public care is unavailable, as services carry both a 
formal and informal charge. Out-of-pocket spending is estimated at $7 per person per year. 
The poor often rely on quacks and shops, resulting in poor quality care and income erosion.   
 
15.  Services. The network of infrastructure has grown beyond the financial capacity of 
the Government, at the cost of primary care and quality enhancing expenditures. A large 
number of small health facilities operate with very low attendance or are closed. Substantial 
rationalization of health services is needed, which is a politically sensitive matter. This 
should go along with a redistribution of staff and improving the quality of services through 
better supplies and supervision. Vertical programs are undermining regular services and 
should be integrated. The main reason for pursuing vertical programs is that it fits the 
orientation of the international aid agencies that look for concrete objectives and measurable 
outcomes achieved in a stipulated period of time. These programs ignore the fact that they 
can only be implemented because of existing health services.   
 
16.  Human Resources. According to Department of Health estimates, the sector has an 
approximate sanctioned staff  strength  of  43,626.  An  additional  2,600  staffs  of  defunct 
metropolitan and municipal corporations, district councils, and town committees have been 
brought under the district after devolution. There are about 12,000 doctors, 2,000 nurses, 
and about 12,000  paramedics. Among the doctors in general cadre, 25% are female. The 
doctor population and nurse population are 1:2,932 and 1:8,653, reflecting a major shortage 
of nurses.  The shortage of female staff in Sindh is linked to traditional views on the chastity 
of women. There are quotas allocated to each district for initial recruitment and persons 
domiciled in a particular district are eligible for appointments. However, many staff members 
occupy a rural post while working in an urban institution. Besides social and security

18.  The formulation of annual development plans has now been devolved and is the 
responsibility  of  the  district  team.  Documents  such  as  “devolution  of  powers  and

lie ahead. Many districts have not yet done such systematic assessments, identification of 
priorities and indicators, and development of plans.  Several user-provider groups in Sindh 
are involved in such matters as setting user charges, repair and maintenance, determination 
of  opening  hours,  organizing  women  users  groups,  health  education,  counseling,  peer 
support, and arrangement of transport.    
 
19.  Policy. The National Health Policy, 2001, aims to (i) reduce widespread prevalence 
of communicable diseases, (ii) address imbalances in primary and secondary services, (iii) 
remove professional and managerial deficiencies in the district health system, (iv) promote 
greater gender equity, (v) bridge nutrition gaps in the target population, (vi) correct the urban 
bias in the health sector, (vii) introduce required regulation in the private sector, (viii) create 
mass awareness in public health matters, (ix) effect improvements in the drug sector, and (x) 
build capacity for health policy monitoring. The vision as stated in Population Policy, 2002, is 
to  achieve  population  stabilization  by  2020.  The  Government  of  Pakistan’s  10-Year 
perspective plan (2001–2011) spells out the essential program elements that need to be in 
place to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). The Sindh Poverty Reduction 
Strategy spells out the objectives in primary health care for the period 2001–2005.  
 
20.  To capitalize on the opportunity of devolution in the health sector, a critical mass of 
active and committed leaders will be needed. The medical associations and colleges should 
also be brought on board. Current management strengthening needs to be followed with 
increased delegation of authority, improved planning to rationalize services, and improved 
flow of funds. Strong political commitment is needed to contain the expansion of medical 
colleges and tertiary hospitals. Training and working conditions for female staff need to be 
improved. At the community level, efforts should be made to develop health boards to 
maintain and operate the health services.  
 
C.  Rural Water Supply and Sanitation 
 
21.  Status. Two thirds of Sindh lies either in the brackish water zone or in the desert 
zone, and 17% in the sweet water zone. Rainfall is very low, and most rural people get water 
from the Indus River and its irrigation system, which is also under threat. The 18 million rural 
people live in 5,871 scattered villages, two thirds of which have a population of less than 
5,000. In rural areas, piped water supply covers 14% and hand pumps 41%. The remaining 
45% of households rely on unsafe water, such as uncovered wells, rivers, and rain-fed or 
canal-fed ponds that are often located at considerable distance from the homes. The burden 
of fetching water usually falls on women and girls. Overdrawing with mechanized pumps and 
poor maintenance of schemes cause water shortages. The water and sanitation sector

(WSS) infrastructure was often developed without analyzing maintenance and recurrent cost 
needs, and without a master plan. Several hundred schemes that were politically motivated 
and  poorly  designed  have  been  abandoned.  Experience  has  also  shown  that  most 
communities can afford only low-cost services.  
 
22.  In both rural and urban areas, drinking water is often polluted and distributed without 
treatment. Sewerage treatment is absent except partially in Karachi. The lower income group 
is most affected by polluted water and water-related diseases. About 53% of the rural 
population lacks access to private toilet facilities including pit latrines. Many schools lack 
proper latrines, posing a problem for girls. Garbage litters the landscape. With the current 
trend, the MDGs for the water sector are unlikely to be reached.     
   
23.  Roles.  Since  devolution,  the  Public  Health  Engineering  Department  has  been 
merged with the local government department and responsibilities for planning and operating 
schemes have been devolved to taluka/town municipal administrations (TMAs). The director 
general (Public Health Engineering) at Hyderabad and district executive officers were to 
provide support for TMAs. The taluka officers (Infrastructure) were made responsible for 
water supply and control and development of water resources, sewage treatment and 
disposal, drainage, sanitation and solid waste collection, among others. However, TMAs 
have not assumed this new role due to lack of funds, authority, and capacity to execute the 
new responsibilities. For example, many engineers are still to be posted from the district to 
the TMAs. The other bottleneck is the low procurement ceiling of goods and services.  
 
24.  The private sector has been discouraged from getting involved in the sector due to 
difficulties in collecting user charges and lack of legislative protection. The National Rural 
Support Program, the Provincial Rural Support Program, and other large nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs) are playing an important role in community development in the sector.  
 
25.  Financing. TMAs can barely afford the establishment charges and related costs. 
Integration of municipal services has overstaffed the TMAs whose capacity to collect local 
revenue, such as octroi, has also been curtailed. Communities have come to rely on the 
Government  for  financing  the  operation  and  maintenance  costs  of  services.  Many 
households cannot afford the excessive billings due to mismanagement of schemes. The 
government of Sindh (SPG) decided to deduct payments at source, resulting in an almost 
total lack of funds for operation and maintenance for the past 2 years. TMA revenue 
collection has also been curtailed.        
 
26.  Policy and Plans. The SPG has resolved to continue implementing the rural WSS 
programs in accordance with its uniform policy framework, which is promoting community 
ownership and management of operation and maintenance of schemes. However, the newly 
installed TMAs are not familiar with this approach. SPG plans to build the capacity of TMAs 
through  posting  of  professional  staff  and  training,  and  establish  TMAs  in  all  aspects 
(financial, managerial, technical and social development) to manage the sector. SPG will 
transfer funds directly to TMAs.  The directorate general at Hyderabad and district support 
units will have a coordinating and support role. The Government wants to involve local 
NGOs in community development activities and to build the capacity of TMAs.  SPG wants 
to support each TMA to undertake surveys to (i) assess the technical and financial viability of 
each scheme; (ii) operationalize viable, need-based schemes; and (iii) execute small new 
water supply and sanitation schemes in rural areas. To provide water supply to the presently 
uncovered population in Sindh, PRs67.5 billion or $1.2 billion would be required. SPG also 
plans  to  improve  garbage  disposal  with  the  assistance  of  the  private  sector,  provide 
incentives for latrines, and repair or replace urban sewerage systems. 5

A.  Sector Financing 
 
1.  Sindh Economy. Pakistan’s gross domestic product (GDP) was about PRs3.73 billion 
($63.7 billion equivalent) in FY2002. Sindh’s economy contributes 30% of the GDP compared to 
a population share of about 25%, the difference being explained by the economic hub of 
Karachi. Half of Sindh’s population live in the urban areas. The per capita income is about $450 
per person per year. Poverty has increased from 27% in FY1999 to 37% in 2001. About one 
third of the urban and two thirds of the rural population are poor, living on less than a dollar a 
day.  
 
2.  Sindh Revenue. The budget of the Sindh provincial government (SPG) was PRs80.7 
billion  ($1.4 billion) in FY2003, or 7.2% of the provincial GDP, to serve the economy of 
approximately 35 million people. The budget includes 82% federal transfers (taxes and nontax 
transfers), 16% provincial revenue receipts, and 2% development grants. Federal transfers have 
on average increased 17.6% since FY1998, compared with an  annual growth of 12.7% for 
provincial receipts. The level of development grants has not been constant in the last 6 years; 
the amount was close to zero in FY2000 but was PRs4.2 billion ($72 million) in FY2002 (Table 
A6.1). 
 
3.  Public Sector Budget. The total budget for FY2003 was PRs99.3 billion, including 94% 
recurrent expenditures and 6% development expenditures, including the annual development 
program and  foreign project assistance. The recurrent expenditure in these social sectors 
increased at an average annual growth rate of 16.7% in the past 6 years, exceeding receipts in 
the last 6 years. Contrary to recurrent spending, development  spending decreased between 
FY1998 and FY2001 due to a decline in foreign project assistance, but recovered from FY2002 
onward. The total fiscal deficit in FY2003 was PRs18.7 billion (about $322 million). Before  
FY2001, SPG replaced federal loans with domestic borrowing. But in view of high interest rates 
now, SPG wants to replace domestic loans with foreign borrowing. In FY2003, SPG reduced 
domestic loans to 52% and used foreign loans for the remaining 48%. SPG had a total debt of 
PRs109.6 billion (about $2 billion) in FY2001, of which 59% was foreign, 39% federal, and 2% 
domestic. The revenues are expected to increase by 22% in FY2005, and by 11% in the 
following years.      
 
4.  Social Sector Budget.  The recurrent budget for major social services (education, 
health, and water and sanitation) was 29%, compared with general administration 22%, and 
debt servicing 14% in FY2002. The budgets for education, health and water and sanitation are 
respectively, 73%, 24%, and 3% of total spending in the major social sectors in FY2003 (Table 
A6.2) The budget in the water and sanitation sector is currently at an all-time low. The recurrent 
budget in education, health and water and sanitation was respectively 83%, 93%, and 77%. 
Similarly, the nonsalary budget as a share of recurrent budget was 9%, 20%, and 21%, 
respectively.     
   
5.  Overall, the total social sector budget (both revenue and development expenditures) has 
increased by 11.0% per year. Between FY2000 and FY2003, social sector recurrent budgets 
have increased by 11.4% per year on average (10.7% for education, 13.5% for health, and 
12.5% for [WSS]). The total social sector development budget increased by an average annual 
growth rate of 6.9% (21.6% for education, and 10.2% for health, per year, while that for water 
supply and sanitation declined by 29.8%).

B.  Allocation of Funds

Program (DSSP) is the method used to transfer funds to local governments from the Khushal 
Pakistan Program (a poverty reduction initiative of the federal Government), which distributes 
funds based on population (70%) and backwardness (30%). The population data is sourced 
from the population census carried out by the federal Government in 1998, while backwardness 
is sourced from the deprivation index generated by the Social Policy and Development Center, 
ranking districts in Sindh on the basis of 26 socioeconomic indicators. The DSSP funds are

concerned signing a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the provincial government,

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Pakistan (Sindh Province): 
About half of Sindh’s population of 35 million live in urban areas, with the majority of them concentrated in the main 
cities of Karachi, Hyderabad, and Sukkur. Sindh has the highest concentration of the poor in Pakistan with the figure 
increasing from 27% in 1999 to 37% in 2001. Two thirds of the poor live in rural areas. Poverty; gender imbalance; 
weak management; and poor service delivery in education, health, and water supply have contributed to high mortality 
and malnutrition rates, stagnating school enrollment and high population growth in Sindh. 
 
The Government’s poverty reduction strategy and program calls for major reforms in public sector governance, and 
increased allocation and efforts for improving social services. The Sindh provincial government (SPG) has prepared a 
poverty reduction strategy and wants to strengthen devolution in the social sectors. The devolution is under way since 
August  2001.  Local  governments  (LGs)  are  functioning  at  the  district,  taluka,  and  union  level.  As  per  Local 
Government Ordinance, district governments have been given responsibility for basic education and health services, 
and taluka municipal administrations for water and sanitation services. The devolution policy anticipates that the LG 
structure will improve the efficiency of allocating public resources in accordance with local needs, and enhance quality, 
efficiency, accountability, and ownership of such services.  
 
The poverty partnership agreement between the Government of Pakistan and Asian Development Bank (ADB) reflects 
the Government’s vision for poverty reduction, including the need for improving social services for the poor. The major 
theme of ADB’s country strategy program is governance reform including in the social sector. ADB supports the 
Government’s governance reforms through the Decentralization Support Program and other programs. The proposed 
Sindh Devolved Social Services Program  (DSSP) supports the Sindh Reform Program, the Poverty Reduction 
Strategy and the devolution to LGs in the social sectors.  
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Proposed Classification: Poverty Intervention 
About one third of Sindh’s population live on less than a dollar a day, about two thirds of them in rural areas, with 
pockets of extreme poverty. Sindh faces lack of basic services, high incidence of health problems, low literacy rate, 
high population growth, lack of rule of law, lack of access to justice and empowerment, inaccessibility of capital, 
increased unemployment, and weak service delivery. Social sector indicators in Sindh are very poor. Half of the 
children below age of 5 years are malnourished, and 11% of them die before the age of 5.  Of the survivors, half do 
not attend school. The total fertility rate is 5 children per woman. Only a quarter of the rural population have access to 
safe drinking water. The poor social indicators are linked to complex political and social organizations, poverty, gender 
discrimination, run-down social services, and governance problems.        
 
The rural society of Sindh is heterogeneous in terms of ethnicity, tribes, and caste. Social relationships are based on 
caste, tribe, and language. The two major rural groups are Sindhi and Baluchi. In addition, there are Punjabi, Pathan, 
Bihari, and Hindu scheduled castes. The Hindu scheduled caste constitutes 6.5% of the population. The scheduled 
caste includes Kholi, Bheel, Parkari Kulhis, Meghwar, and Khumber. Social groups found within rural areas of Sindh 
include landowner (zamindar) sharecroppers (Muslim and Hindu scheduled castes), small and middle farmers, wage 
laborers, fisherfolk, artisans and service households. In addition to differences in castes there are seminomadic clans 
and, in some areas seasonal migrants and the boat people in Manchar Lake. In rural Sindh, status and power are 
conferred by land ownership. The land ownership, relationships of tribes and caste determine much of the political and 
social organization and functioning of the society. The skewed land tenure pattern and high degree of landlessness is 
related to perpetuation of the  zamindar system. The skewed land tenure pattern, very low rainfall and periodic 
droughts, and salination of lands have seriously affected agricultural output, and are contributing to deep rural poverty 
and migration to urban areas at the rate of 6% per year.    
 
During the past decade, Sindh implemented the Social Action Program (SAP) to improve the social sector. The SAP 
experience has mixed outcome. The interrelated economic, governance, and project modalities affected SAP effort.
